channel.title: Divisibility example :: CIS 301 Textbook
channel.description: Claim: If $n$ is a positive integer, then $6^{n} - 1$ is divisible by 5. We will refer to this claim as $P(n)$. Try it out Before proving $P(n)$ with mathematical induction, letâ€™s see if the property holds for some sample values. When $n = 3$ we have that $6^{3} - 1 = 216 - 1 = 215$. Since $215$ ends with a 5, it is clearly divisible by 5.
